messages:
================================ System Message ================================


Upon an agent calling, you must TELL the user with detailed explanation of your reasoning for choosing it. You must give your reason on why you fill in the param of that agent the way you do( even you leave the param empty ). This reasoning part must be super detailed. 
If you want to pass information from one agent to another, you MUST fill in the file_id(or file_ids) param of the agent with the id of the file that contains the information you want to pass.
If you think it's time to stop, you must output in a format shown below:
### workflow ### 
(Summarize the workflow you have done)
### final_result ### 
(The final result of the executions)
------------------------------------
A hypothesis must be considered invalidated if neither of its requested reagents is available.

Current Stage Goal: DNA Sequencing

---
Requirement for this stage:
The input DNA is stored at 4 degrees Celsius.
---

Please focus ONLY on executing this current stage.

================================== Ai Message ==================================

I will call the `Literature` agent to search for information about the DNA sequencing protocol.
The `Literature` agent is a tool that can search the local database of scientific papers for answers to specific questions. I will use it to find a suitable protocol for DNA sequencing, which is the goal of the current stage.

I will fill in the `questions` parameter with "What is the protocol for DNA sequencing?". I am asking this question to get a general protocol for DNA sequencing. This will give me a good starting point for generating a detailed experimental procedure.

I will fill in the `experiment_name` parameter with "DNA Sequencing". This will help the agent to narrow down the search to the relevant experiment.
Tool Calls:
  Literature (4717e437-ba73-4357-b422-765b1f2da5df)
 Call ID: 4717e437-ba73-4357-b422-765b1f2da5df
  Args:
    experiment_name: DNA Sequencing
    questions: ['What is the protocol for DNA sequencing?']

================================= Tool Message =================================
Name: Literature

DNA sequencing protocols vary depending on the technique employed, with common methods including Sanger sequencing, Maxam & Gilbert chemical degradation, Pyrosequencing, and single-molecule sequencing with exonuclease.

### Sanger Method (Enzymic Methods)

The Sanger dideoxy or enzymatic DNA sequencing method utilizes a DNA-dependent DNA polymerase to synthesize a complementary copy of a single-stranded DNA template (Shendure2011 pages 1-2). The polymerase synthesizes a new chain starting at the 3′ end of a primer DNA complementary to a single-stranded "template" DNA strand (Shendure2011 pages 1-2). Dideoxynucleotides (ddNTPs) are incorporated, which lack the 3′-hydroxyl group necessary for further chain elongation, thereby terminating DNA synthesis (Franc2002 pages 3-7; Van2008 pages 13-16).

**Original Chain-Termination Method (Sanger et al. 1977):**
1.  A $^{32}$P-labelled primer (short oligonucleotide complementary to the template DNA) is annealed to a specific known region on the template DNA (Franc2002 pages 3-7).
2.  Catalytic polymerization of deoxynucleoside triphosphates (dNTPs) onto the DNA occurs in the presence of DNA polymerases (Franc2002 pages 3-7).
3.  Polymerization extends until a modified nucleoside, a terminator or ddNTP, is incorporated (Franc2002 pages 3-7).
4.  The reaction is performed in four different tubes, each containing the appropriate amount of one of the four terminators (Franc2002 pages 3-7).
5.  All generated fragments have the same 5′-end, with the residue at the 3′-end determined by the dideoxynucleotide used in the reaction (Franc2002 pages 3-7).
6.  After all four reactions are completed, the mixture of different-sized DNA fragments is resolved by electrophoresis on a denaturing polyacrylamide gel, in four parallel lanes (Franc2002 pages 3-7; Murray1996 pages 4-4).
7.  The unknown sequence is read by autoradiography (Franc2002 pages 3-7).

**Thermal Cycle Sequencing (Cycle Sequencing):**
This protocol was developed to sequence double-stranded DNA templates without the need for independent pre-denaturation steps (Shendure2011 pages 1-2).
1.  A standard PCR thermocycling machine and a sequencing reaction-specific thermocycling program are used (Van2008 pages 13-16).
2.  Both double-stranded and single-stranded DNA template may be used, as the temperature achieved during thermocycling is sufficient to thermally dissociate any double-stranded DNA into single strands (Van2008 pages 13-16).
3.  Cycle sequencing protocols utilize four standard PCR mixes, with each additionally containing one of four labelled chain terminating dideoxynucleotides (either ddATP, ddCTP, ddGTP or ddTTP) (Van2008 pages 13-16).
4.  Only a single (sequencing) primer is added to the sequencing reaction mix, resulting in linear amplification (Van2008 pages 16-20).
5.  The terminated fragments in each of the four sequencing reactions are then separated by electrophoresis in a single polyacrylamide gel (Van2008 pages 16-20).
6.  The labelled fragments are detected using, for example, radioactive sensitive film (e.g., Hyperfilm, Amersham International) (Van2008 pages 16-20).

**Optimized Fast Cycling Protocol (STeP):**
This protocol aims to increase throughput and improve data quality (Platt2007 pages 2-3).
1.  An initial 60 s incubation at 96°C (Platt2007 pages 3-4).
2.  Followed by 25 cycles of: 96°C for 10 s; 50°C for 5 s; and 60°C for 75 s (Platt2007 pages 3-4).
3.  In STeP, the duration of Te (elongation time) is extended by 15 s for cycles 16–20 and an additional 30 s for cycles 21–25 (Platt2007 pages 3-4).
4.  No changes are made to the denaturation or annealing temperatures or times (Platt2007 pages 3-4).
5.  The reaction components are: 0.5 μL BigDye Terminator v3.1, 2.0 μL 5× Sequencing Buffer, 2.0 μL (20 ng) Primer, 2.0 μL (200 ng) DNA, 3.5 μL Deionized Water, for a Total Volume of 10 μL, with a Cycling Time of 55 min (Platt2007 pages 2-3).

**Sample Preparation:**
General steps include (i) DNA scission and cloning into a vector (e.g., M13 or M13mp18); (ii) vector amplification to produce a phage-infected culture; and (iii) purification from the cell culture to yield pure single-stranded (ss)DNA template (Franc2002 pages 7-10).
*   **Random Fragmentation:** Genomic DNA is randomly fragmented (e.g., by sonication or nebulization) into smaller pieces, typically 2 to 3 kb, which are then inserted into a vector and replicated in bacterial culture (Franc2002 pages 3-7).
*   **Purification:** Methods include using exonuclease I and shrimp alkaline phosphatase to degrade excess primers and non-incorporated nucleotides, precipitation by isopropyl alcohol, or plasmid-based amplification in *E. coli* followed by alkaline lysis (Birnboim & Doly, 1979) (Franc2002 pages 7-10).
*   **Generating Single-Stranded DNA:**
    *   Heating double-stranded DNA at 100°C for 5 minutes, followed by "snap-cooling" in ice, a dry-ice/ethanol bath, or liquid nitrogen (Van2008 pages 13-16).
    *   Alkaline denaturation (Van2008 pages 13-16).
    *   Using 5′-end hapten-labelled (e.g., biotin) PCR primers to attach double-stranded PCR products to a solid phase (e.g., streptavidin-coated ELISA plate wells or magnetic beads), followed by removal of the complementary DNA strand (e.g., by alkaline treatment) (Van2008 pages 13-16).
    *   Asymmetric PCR, where one PCR primer is present in a higher concentration (usually 1:50 to 1:100 higher) than the other, generating high concentrations of single-stranded DNA molecules up to 1,000 bp in length (Van2008 pages 11-13, 13-16).
    *   Lambda exonuclease III, a 5′-3′ exonuclease specific for double-stranded DNA requiring a phosphate group at the 5′-end. The procedure involves 5′-end labelling of double-stranded PCR products using T4 polynucleotide kinase and ATP (or a 5′-end phosphorylated primer), followed by exonuclease degradation of the phosphorylated DNA strand (Van2008 pages 13-16).

**Enzyme Technology:**
Initially, isothermal DNA polymerases (e.g., T4 or T7 DNA polymerases) were used at physiological temperatures (approx. 37°C) for approximately 20 minutes (Franc2002 pages 3-7). The discovery of heat-stable DNA polymerase from *Thermus aquaticus* (Taq polymerase) enabled cycle-sequencing with reduced DNA template amounts (Franc2002 pages 3-7). Modified Taq polymerase with equalized ddNTP incorporation rates improved sequencing performance (Franc2002 pages 7-10). PCR enzymes require 3′- to 5′-exonuclease activity (proof-reading), which must be suppressed for cycle-sequencing to avoid un-interpretable data (Franc2002 pages 7-10). Newer, specifically engineered, thermostable DNA polymerases (e.g., Thermosequenase, Sequencing Grade Taq DNA Polymerase, Amplitaq DNA polymerase FS) show improved affinity for ddNTPs, uniform band intensities, and high accuracy (Van2008 pages 16-20).

**Labels and DNA Labelling:**
*   **Radioisotopes:** $^{32}$P was initially used (Franc2002 pages 7-10). Deoxyadenosine 5′-(α-[$^{35}$S]thio)triphosphate ($^{35}$S) increased band sharpness and resolution (Franc2002 pages 7-10). [α-$^{33}$P]dATP provides short exposure times similar to $^{32}$P but band resolution comparable to $^{35}$S (Shendure2011 pages 3-4).
*   **Chemiluminescent Detection:** The biotin–streptavidin system uses a 5′-end biotin-linked oligonucleotide as a primer. Alkaline phosphatase, bound to the 5′-end via a streptavidin conjugate, catalyzes a luminescent reaction detected by photographic film (Franc2002 pages 7-10).
*   **Fluorescent Dyes:**
    *   **Four-Dye, Single-Lane Separation:** Smith et al. (1986) developed a set of four different fluorescent dyes (fluorescein, 4-chloro-7-nitrobenzo-2-1-diazole (NBD), tetramethyl-rhodamine, and Texas Red) (Franc2002 pages 10-12). Each dye is attached to the 5′-end of the primer and associated with a particular ddNTP (e.g., fluorescein-labelled primer with ddCTP, tetramethyl-rhodamine-labelled primer with ddATP). All four reactions are combined and introduced onto a slab gel in a single lane. Bands are detected by laser excitation at the end of the gel, and fluorescent light is separated by four different colored filters (Franc2002 pages 10-12).
    *   **Dye-labelled Primer Chemistry:** Fluorescent labels are attached at the 5′-end of the primer, requiring four separate reactions (Franc2002 pages 10-12).
    *   **Dye-labelled Terminator Chemistry:** The fluorescent moiety is linked to the ddNTP terminators, allowing the synthesis of all four ladders in a single vial (Franc2002 pages 10-12; Van2008 pages 16-20).
    *   **Alternative Dyes:** Tetramethyl-rhodamine (λexc ≈ 560 nm, λem ≈ 575 nm, FWHM ≈ 52 nm), fluorescein iodoacetamine, carboxyfluorescein (FAM), carboxy-4′,5′-dichloro-2′,7′-dimethoxyfluorescein (JOE), carboxytetramethyl-rhodamine (TAMRA), and carboxy-X-rhodamine (ROX) are commonly used. FAM and JOE require 488 nm excitation, while TAMRA and ROX require 543 nm (Franc2002 pages 10-12). Base-specific succinylfluorescein dyes (SF-xxx) and dipyrrometheneborondifluoride fluorophores (BODIPY) are also utilized (Franc2002 pages 10-12).
    *   **Energy Transfer (ET) Dyes:** Consist of two dyes per primer: a common donor (e.g., fluorescein (FAM) or cyanine (Cy5) derivative) at the 5′-end and an acceptor dye (e.g., FAM, JOE, TAMRA, ROX) located approximately 10 bases along the primer. These dyes can be almost evenly excited by a single wavelength (488 nm) and exhibit minimal electrophoretic mobility shifts (Franc2002 pages 10-12).
    *   **One-Tube Cycle Sequencing:** Uses non-radioactive, fluorescent-based dye labels chemically attached to dideoxynucleotidetriphosphates, each fluorescing with specific spectral characteristics (e.g., FAM, HEX, TAMRA, ROX) (Van2008 pages 16-20). All four tagged ddNTPs are added to a single cycle sequencing reaction mix. After thermocycling, the terminated DNA fragments are separated by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, excited by a static laser, and the fluorescence is measured (Van2008 pages 16-20).

**Fragment Separation and Analysis:**
*   **Electrophoresis:** Denaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis is a standard method (Franc2002 pages 3-7). Capillary Electrophoresis (CE) using polymer solutions is 8–10 times faster per lane than slab gels, and Capillary Array Electrophoresis (CAE) instruments can run 96 samples simultaneously (Franc2002 pages 14-16).
*   **Mass Spectrometry (MS):**
    *   **Matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization–time of flight (MALDI–TOF) MS:** The sample is co-crystallized with an energy-absorbing compound (e.g., aromatic amine or carboxylic acid). A laser pulse at the matrix's absorption maximum vaporizes the matrix, expelling and ionizing sample molecules via proton-exchange reactions. Ions are then accelerated and separated by their mass-to-charge ratio in a drift tube (Franc2002 pages 14-16).
    *   **Electrospray ionization (ESI) MS:** Used for detecting short oligomers by negative ion mode MS (Franc2002 pages 14-16).

### Maxam & Gilbert and Other Chemical Methods

This method involves subjecting end-labelled DNA fragments to random cleavage at adenine, cytosine, guanine, or thymine positions using specific chemical agents (Franc2002 pages 14-16). The chemical attack proceeds in three steps: base modification, removal of the modified base from its sugar, and DNA strand breaking at that sugar position (Franc2002 pages 14-16).

**Template:** Double-stranded (ds)DNA or ssDNA from chromosomal DNA can be used. Fragments are generally digested with an appropriate restriction enzyme (Maxam & Gilbert, 1980) (Franc2002 pages 14-16).

**End-Labelling:**
*   Originally performed with [$^{32}$P]phosphate or a nucleotide linked to $^{32}$P and enzymically incorporated into the end fragment (Franc2002 pages 14-16).
*   Alternatively, restriction fragments are labelled through [$^{35}$S]dideoxyadenosine 5′-(α-thio)triphosphate ([$^{35}$S]ddATPαS) and terminal deoxynucleotidyltransferase (Franc2002 pages 14-16).
*   Non-radioactive labelling includes a 21-mer fluorescein-labelled M13 sequencing primer (Franc2002 pages 14-16).
*   A biotin marker molecule can be chemically or enzymically attached to an oligonucleotide primer or enzymically attached to an end-filling reaction of restriction enzyme sites (Franc2002 pages 16-18).
*   PCR can be used to amplify products where one of the primers is end-labelled (Franc2002 pages 16-18).

**Chemical Cleavage Reactions:**
*   **Four-lane methods:** Four (or more) separate cleavage procedures are used, with information displayed in four (or more) parallel gel lanes (Franc2002 pages 18-20).
    *   **G+A:** Dimethyl sulphate (DMS) followed by heating at pH 7/0.1 M alkali at 90 °C (Franc2002 pages 16-18).
    *   **A+G:** DMS-acid/alkali (Franc2002 pages 16-18).
    *   **C+T:** Hydrazine at 20 °C (Franc2002 pages 16-18).
    *   **C:** Hydrazine-2 M NaCl (Franc2002 pages 16-18).
    *   Almost all base-specific reactions are followed by treatment with hot aqueous piperidine (Franc2002 pages 16-18).
*   **One-lane (or two-lane) methods:** All reactions are based on only one chemical modification, and electrophoresis is performed in a single (or two) lane(s) (Franc2002 pages 18-20).
    *   The first single-lane method used hot aqueous piperidine for several hours (Ambrose & Pless, 1985) (Franc2002 pages 18-20).
    *   A two-lane method involves heating the labelled DNA fragment in the presence of formamide, resulting in efficient cleavage of the phosphodiester bond at 3′ residues A, C, and G, with relative efficiency A ≈ G > C. The bias between A and G is obtained through a pretreatment consisting of a photoreaction with Methylene Blue (Negri et al. 1991) (Franc2002 pages 18-20).
    *   Another single-lane method determines the DNA sequence by monitoring the intensities of bands representing cleavage products at the four bases, obtained by solvolysis in hot aqueous piperidine (10%) followed by treatment with hot formamide (Ferraboli et al. 1993) (Franc2002 pages 18-20). Guanine sensitivity can be increased by using inosine instead of guanosine residues, and adenine sensitivity decreased by substituting them with their diazo derivatives (Saladino et al. 1996) (Franc2002 pages 18-20). N-methylformamide in the presence of manganese has also yielded satisfactory results (Negri et al. 1996) (Franc2002 pages 18-20).

**Fragment Separation and Detection:**
Products of these reactions are separated using polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (Franc2002 pages 14-16). Chemiluminescent detection involves transferring the chemically cleaved DNA fragment from a sequencing gel onto a nylon membrane. Specific sequences are then selected by hybridization to DNA oligonucleotides labelled with alkaline phosphatase or biotin. The membrane is soaked in the chemiluminescent substrate (AMPPD) and exposed to photographic film (Franc2002 pages 16-18). MALDI–TOF MS has also been used to separate the products of Maxam–Gilbert reactions (Isola et al. 1999) (Franc2002 pages 16-18).

**Automation and Solid-Phase Techniques:**
*   A computer-controlled microchemical robot can carry out one of the four reactions (G, A+C, C+T, or C) in less than 2 hours (Wada et al. 1983; Wada, 1984) (Franc2002 pages 16-18).
*   DNA can be immobilized by adsorption to DEAE paper (Whatman DE 81 paper) (Chuvpilo & Kravchenko, 1984) (Franc2002 pages 16-18).
*   A new carrier medium, CCS anion-exchange paper (Whatman 540 paper activated with cyanuric chloride and then reacted with 2-bromo-ethylamine hydrobromide), provides excellent stability (Rosenthal et al. 1985, 1986; Rosenthal, 1987) (Franc2002 pages 16-18).
*   Reverse-phase chromatography (C18-filled mini-columns) works for both short and long DNA fragments (Jagadeeswaran & Kaul, 1986) (Franc2002 pages 16-18).
*   DNA immobilized on streptavidin-coated magnetic beads has been used (Ohara & Ohara, 1995). An improvement involved a PCR-primer linked to biotin and fluorescein at the 5′-end, replacing the piperidine evaporation step with a magnetic-capture washing cycle (Ohara et al. 1997) (Franc2002 pages 16-18).

### Pyrosequencing

Pyrosequencing is a real-time DNA-sequencing method based on the detection of pyrophosphate (PPi) released during the DNA polymerization reaction (Nyrén & Lundin, 1985; Hyman, 1988; Ronaghi et al. 1996) (Franc2002 pages 18-20).

**Enzymic Cascade:**
1.  **DNA polymerase:** When one of the deoxynucleotides (dATP, dCTP, dGTP, or dTTP) is incorporated into the chain extension by DNA polymerase, PPi is released: (DNA)n-dNTP → (DNA)n+1-PPi (Franc2002 pages 18-20).
2.  **ATP sulphurylase:** The liberated PPi is then converted into ATP by ATP sulphurylase: PPi + APS → ATP + SO4^2- (where APS is adenosine 5′-phosphosulphate) (Franc2002 pages 18-20).
3.  **Luciferase:** Light is emitted via firefly luciferase, which catalyzes luciferin into oxyluciferin: ATP + luciferin + O2 → AMP + PPi + oxyluciferin + CO2 + hν (where hν represents a photon) (Franc2002 pages 18-20).

**Sequence Determination:** The sequence is determined by noting if incorporations occur and by counting the number of incorporations (by measuring the light intensity). The amount of light emitted can be measured by an avalanche photodiode, photomultiplier tube, or a charged-coupled device camera (Franc2002 pages 18-20).

**Approaches:**
*   **Solid-phase sequencing (three-enzyme mixture):** Requires a template-washing step between nucleotide additions to remove non-incorporated deoxynucleotides and ATP. The template must be bound to a solid support (e.g., a magnetic bead) (Franc2002 pages 18-20).
*   **Liquid-phase sequencing (four-enzyme mixture):** A nucleotide-degrading enzyme (e.g., apyrase) is added to eliminate washing steps; unreacted nucleotides and ATP produced are degraded by the enzyme (Franc2002 pages 18-20).

**Improvements/Modifications:**
*   Using ssDNA-binding proteins (SSB) to displace primers that bind non-specifically to the target DNA template, minimizing non-specific signals (Ronaghi, 2000) (Franc2002 pages 18-20). This strategy increased enzyme efficiency, reduced mispriming, increased signal intensity, and yielded higher accuracy in reading the number of identical adjacent nucleotides in difficult templates (Franc2002 pages 20-23).
*   A simplified enzymic method for template preparation makes possible the use of dsDNA (Nordstrom et al. 2000a, b) (Franc2002 pages 20-23).
*   Replacing dATP with dATPαS in the trial step solves the interference of dATP in luminescence detection, as dATPαS is efficiently incorporated by DNA polymerase but does not function as a substrate for luciferase (Ronaghi et al. 1996) (Franc2002 pages 20-23).

**Template Preparation:** ssDNA, amplified by PCR, must be used (Franc2002 pages 20-23).

### Single Molecule Sequencing with Exonuclease

This laser-based technique allows fast sequencing of DNA fragments of 40 kb or more at a rate of 100–1000 bases per second (Jett et al. 1989) (Franc2002 pages 20-23). It is based on the detection of individual fluorescent nucleotides in a flowing sample stream (Shera et al. 1990; Harding & Keller, 1992) (Franc2002 pages 20-23).

**Steps:**
1.  **Fluorescent labelling of bases:** Every base in one strand is completely labelled, with each nucleotide type labelled with a characteristic dye possessing large fluorescence quantum yields and distinguishable spectral properties (Dörre et al. 1997) (Franc2002 pages 20-23).
2.  **Attachment of labelled DNA fragment:** A single DNA strand (e.g., 5′-biotinylated DNA) is selected and attached to a streptavidin-coated microsphere (Stephan et al. 2001) (Franc2002 pages 20-23). Only one DNA fragment must be attached to the microsphere (Davis et al. 1991; Goodwin et al. 1997) (Franc2002 pages 23-25).
3.  **Movement of supported DNA fragment:** The microsphere with the attached DNA fragment is moved into a flowing buffer stream (Franc2002 pages 20-23).
4.  **Digestion with exonuclease:** An exonuclease is added to the 3′-end of the labelled DNA fragment in the flow stream, initiating the sequential cleavage of bases from the 3′- to the 5′-end of the DNA (Franc2002 pages 23-25). The rate of cleavage can be adjusted by varying the exonuclease concentration, cofactor concentration, temperature, or by using inhibitors (Davis et al. 1991) (Franc2002 pages 23-25).
5.  **Detection and identification:** Individual fluorescently labelled bases are detected and identified as they cross a focused laser beam (Franc2002 pages 20-23).

**Detection Methods:**
*   Photon-burst detection, where photon bursts are correlated in time to distinguish them from background (Greenless et al. 1977) (Franc2002 pages 23-25).
*   Time-correlated single-photon counting in combination with mode-locked picosecond-pulsed excitation (Wilkerson et al. 1993) (Franc2002 pages 23-25).
*   Surface-enhanced Raman scattering for detecting single DNA base molecules (Kneipp et al. 1998) (Franc2002 pages 23-25).
*   A confocal set-up for detection and identification of single molecules in solution (Eigen & Rigler, 1994) (Franc2002 pages 23-25).
*   A multiplex technique for identifying single fluorescent molecules in a flowing sample stream by correlated measurement of single-molecule fluorescence burst size and intraburst fluorescence decay rate (Van Orden et al. 1998) (Franc2002 pages 23-25).

**Oxford Nanopore Technology (as of 2011, not commercially available):** This method uses exonuclease I or a modified phi29 polymerase coupled to a plate in parallel spots, surrounded by a lipid bilayer incorporating MspA or alpha hemolysin with electrodes on both sides. When DNA is introduced, the exonuclease progressively cleaves the terminal nucleotide that enters the nanopore (Shendure2011 pages 16-17).

**Heliscope Sequencing:**
In Heliscope sequencing, single-stranded fragments are applied to a flow cell with billions of oligo(dT) molecules covalently bound to the glass surface. The flow cell captures individual library fragments by hybridization of the poly(dA) tailed fragments to oligo(dT) (Shendure2011 pages 16-17). Fluorescent nucleotides are pumped in one at a time (Shendure2011 pages 16-17).
 The information has been saved to the file: Literature-cfb5

================================== Ai Message ==================================

I have identified a suitable protocol for your experiment. The Sanger method, specifically the thermal cycle sequencing with fluorescent dye-labeled terminators, is a well-established and reliable choice for DNA sequencing. I will now generate a detailed experimental procedure based on this method.

I will use the `Protocol` agent to generate the procedure. Here's my reasoning for the parameters I've chosen:

- `experiment_name`: I've set this to "DNA Sequencing" to reflect the goal of the current stage.
- `file_ids`: I'm providing the file ID of the literature search result (`Literature-cfb5`). This file contains a wealth of information about various DNA sequencing protocols, and the `Protocol` agent will use this information to construct a detailed and accurate procedure. I am not including any other parameters as they are not relevant at this stage.
Tool Calls:
  Protocol (24d6245a-8a40-4ad8-9004-c3246d8d3af5)
 Call ID: 24d6245a-8a40-4ad8-9004-c3246d8d3af5
  Args:
    experiment_name: DNA Sequencing
    file_ids: ['Literature-cfb5']

================================= Tool Message =================================
Name: Protocol

Part 1: DNA Template Preparation

    Step 1.1: Fragment genomic DNA into smaller pieces.

        Option 1.1.1: Mechanical fragmentation by sonication.
            - Component A: Genomic DNA
            - Component B: Buffer
            (operational details: Subject the DNA solution to high-frequency sound waves to induce random fragmentation. The duration and intensity of sonication control the resulting fragment size.)

        Option 1.1.2: Mechanical fragmentation by nebulization.
            - Component A: Genomic DNA
            - Component B: Buffer
            (operational details: Force a DNA solution through a small hole in a nebulizer unit, shearing the DNA into smaller fragments. Fragment size is determined by the pressure of the gas used.)

    Step 1.2: Generate single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) template.

        Option 1.2.1: Thermal denaturation of double-stranded DNA.
            - Component A: double-stranded DNA
            - Component B: Buffer
            (operational details: Heat the double-stranded DNA solution to 100°C for 5 minutes to separate the strands. Immediately "snap-cool" the solution on ice, in a dry-ice/ethanol bath, or in liquid nitrogen to prevent re-annealing.)

        Option 1.2.2: Alkaline denaturation of double-stranded DNA.
            - Component A: double-stranded DNA
            - Component B: alkaline solution
            (operational details: Treat the double-stranded DNA with an alkaline solution to disrupt hydrogen bonds and separate the strands.)

        Option 1.2.3: Asymmetric PCR amplification.
            - Component A: double-stranded DNA template
            - Component B: Forward PCR primer (limiting concentration)
            - Component C: Reverse PCR primer (excess concentration, 1:50 to 1:100 ratio)
            - Component D: dNTPs
            - Component E: thermostable DNA polymerase
            - Component F: PCR Buffer
            (operational details: Perform a PCR reaction with an unequal concentration of primers. The limiting primer will be exhausted early in the reaction, leading to the linear amplification of the strand primed by the excess primer, resulting in a high concentration of ssDNA.)

        Option 1.2.4: Solid-phase capture and strand separation.
            - Component A: double-stranded PCR products (generated using a 5'-end hapten-labelled primer, e.g., biotin)
            - Component B: Solid phase support (e.g., streptavidin-coated magnetic beads or ELISA plate wells)
            - Component C: alkaline solution
            (operational details: Bind the biotin-labeled double-stranded PCR product to the streptavidin-coated solid phase. Wash to remove unbound DNA. Add an alkaline solution to denature the DNA, then wash away the non-biotinylated complementary strand, leaving the immobilized ssDNA template.)

        Option 1.2.5: Enzymatic degradation using Lambda exonuclease III.
            - Component A: double-stranded PCR products
            - Component B: T4 polynucleotide kinase
            - Component C: ATP
            - Component D: Lambda exonuclease III
            (operational details: First, phosphorylate the 5'-ends of the double-stranded PCR products using T4 polynucleotide kinase and ATP (unless a 5'-end phosphorylated primer was used for PCR). Then, treat with Lambda exonuclease III, which specifically degrades the 5'-phosphorylated strand of the dsDNA, leaving the non-phosphorylated ssDNA template.)

    Step 1.3: Purify DNA template and remove unincorporated reaction components.

        Option 1.3.1: Enzymatic degradation of primers and nucleotides.
            - Component A: DNA template from a prior reaction
            - Component B: exonuclease I
            - Component C: shrimp alkaline phosphatase
            (operational details: Incubate the reaction products with exonuclease I to degrade single-stranded primers and shrimp alkaline phosphatase to dephosphorylate unincorporated dNTPs. The enzymes are then heat-inactivated.)

        Option 1.3.2: Alcohol precipitation.
            - Component A: DNA template from a prior reaction
            - Component B: isopropyl alcohol
            - Component C: salt solution (e.g. NaCl)
            (operational details: Add salt and isopropyl alcohol to the DNA solution to precipitate the DNA template. Centrifuge to pellet the DNA, wash with ethanol, and resuspend in a suitable buffer.)

        Option 1.3.3: Plasmid amplification and alkaline lysis.
            - Component A: *E. coli* culture containing the DNA of interest cloned into a plasmid vector
            - Component B: Lysis Buffer (containing NaOH and SDS)
            - Component C: Neutralization Buffer (containing acetate)
            (operational details: Grow an *E. coli* culture containing the plasmid. Pellet the cells and perform alkaline lysis to lyse the cells and denature chromosomal and plasmid DNA. Neutralize the solution, which causes the large chromosomal DNA and proteins to precipitate, while the smaller plasmid DNA renatures and remains in solution. Purify the plasmid DNA from the supernatant.)

Part 2: Sanger (Enzymatic) Sequencing

    Step 2.1: Set up the chain-termination reaction.

        Option 2.1.1: Classic method with radiolabeled primer (four tubes).
            - Component A: Purified ssDNA template
            - Component B: $^{32}$P-labelled primer
            - Component C: DNA polymerase (e.g., T4 or T7 DNA polymerase)
            - Component D: Mix of all four deoxynucleoside triphosphates (dNTPs)
            - Component E: One of four dideoxynucleoside triphosphates (ddATP, ddCTP, ddGTP, or ddTTP)
            (operational details: Prepare four separate reaction tubes. Each tube contains the template, labeled primer, polymerase, and dNTP mix. Add a small amount of a single ddNTP to each respective tube (ddATP to tube 1, ddCTP to tube 2, etc.). Incubate at 37°C for approximately 20 minutes.)

        Option 2.1.2: Cycle sequencing with labeled terminators (single tube).
            - Component A: double-stranded or single-stranded DNA template
            - Component B: sequencing primer
            - Component C: Thermostable DNA polymerase (e.g., Thermosequenase, Amplitaq DNA polymerase FS)
            - Component D: Mix of all four dNTPs
            - Component E: All four ddNTPs, each labeled with a distinct fluorescent dye (e.g., FAM, HEX, TAMRA, ROX)
            (operational details: Combine all components into a single reaction tube. Perform thermocycling to linearly amplify the template, generating a population of fluorescently labeled fragments of varying lengths.)

        Option 2.1.3: Cycle sequencing with labeled primers (four tubes).
            - Component A: double-stranded or single-stranded DNA template
            - Component B: One of four sequencing primers, each labeled at the 5'-end with a distinct fluorescent dye (e.g., fluorescein, tetramethyl-rhodamine)
            - Component C: Thermostable DNA polymerase
            - Component D: Mix of all four dNTPs
            - Component E: One of four ddNTPs (ddATP, ddCTP, ddGTP, or ddTTP)
            (operational details: Prepare four separate reactions. Each reaction contains the DNA template, polymerase, dNTPs, one specific ddNTP, and the corresponding dye-labeled primer. Perform thermocycling.)

        Option 2.1.4: STeP (Optimized Fast Cycling Protocol).
            - Component A: BigDye Terminator v3.1
            - Component B: 5× Sequencing Buffer
            - Component C: Primer
            - Component D: DNA
            - Component E: Deionized Water
            (operational details: Combine components for a 10 μL total reaction volume as specified: 0.5 μL BigDye Terminator v3.1, 2.0 μL 5× Sequencing Buffer, 2.0 μL Primer (20 ng), 2.0 μL DNA (200 ng), 3.5 μL Deionized Water. Perform the specific STeP thermocycling program.)

    Step 2.2: Execute thermocycling program for cycle sequencing options.

        Option 2.2.1: Standard thermocycling program.
            (operational details: Use a standard PCR thermocycling machine. A typical program consists of an initial denaturation step, followed by 25-35 cycles of denaturation (e.g., 96°C), primer annealing (e.g., 50-55°C), and extension (e.g., 60-72°C).)

        Option 2.2.2: STeP thermocycling program.
            (operational details: Perform an initial incubation at 96°C for 60 seconds. Follow with 25 cycles of: 96°C for 10 s; 50°C for 5 s; and 60°C for 75 s. The elongation time (Te) is extended by 15 s for cycles 16–20 and by an additional 30 s for cycles 21–25.)

    Step 2.3: Separate and detect sequencing fragments.

        Option 2.3.1: Denaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis with autoradiography.
            - Component A: Products from radiolabeled sequencing reactions
            - Component B: Denaturing polyacrylamide gel
            - Component C: Radioactive sensitive film (e.g., Hyperfilm)
            (operational details: Load the products from the four separate reactions into four parallel lanes of a denaturing polyacrylamide gel. After electrophoresis, expose the gel to radioactive sensitive film to visualize the DNA bands via autoradiography.)

        Option 2.3.2: Denaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis with fluorescence detection.
            - Component A: Products from fluorescently labeled sequencing reactions
            - Component B: Denaturing polyacrylamide gel
            (operational details: Combine the products from the four dye-primer reactions (if used) and load into a single lane, or load the single-tube dye-terminator reaction into one lane. During or after electrophoresis, a laser excites the fluorescent dyes, and detectors with appropriate filters record the emission, determining the terminal base for each fragment size.)

        Option 2.3.3: Capillary Electrophoresis (CE) with fluorescence detection.
            - Component A: Products from fluorescently labeled sequencing reactions
            - Component B: Polymer solution for CE
            (operational details: Inject the sample into a capillary filled with a polymer solution. Apply a high voltage to separate the fragments by size. A laser at the end of the capillary excites the fluorescent labels, and a detector records the sequence.)

        Option 2.3.4: MALDI-TOF Mass Spectrometry.
            - Component A: Products from sequencing reactions
            - Component B: Energy-absorbing matrix (e.g., aromatic amine or carboxylic acid)
            (operational details: Co-crystallize the DNA fragments with the matrix on a target plate. A laser pulse vaporizes and ionizes the molecules. The ions are accelerated, and their time of flight to a detector is measured, which corresponds to their mass-to-charge ratio, allowing for separation and identification.)

Part 3: Maxam-Gilbert (Chemical) Sequencing

    Step 3.1: End-label the DNA fragment.

        Option 3.1.1: 5'-end radioactive labeling with T4 Polynucleotide Kinase.
            - Component A: DNA fragment
            - Component B: [$^{32}$P]phosphate
            - Component C: T4 polynucleotide kinase
            (operational details: Enzymatically transfer a $^{32}$P-labeled phosphate group to the 5'-end of the DNA fragment.)

        Option 3.1.2: 3'-end radioactive labeling with Terminal Deoxynucleotidyltransferase.
            - Component A: DNA fragment
            - Component B: [$^{35}$S]dideoxyadenosine 5′-(α-thio)triphosphate ([S]ddATPαS)
            - Component C: terminal deoxynucleotidyltransferase
            (operational details: Enzymatically add a single $^{35}$S-labeled ddATP to the 3'-end of the DNA fragment.)

        Option 3.1.3: Non-radioactive labeling using a fluorescent primer.
            - Component A: DNA fragment
            - Component B: fluorescein-labelled M13 sequencing primer
            - Component C: DNA polymerase
            - Component D: dNTPs
            (operational details: Use the labeled primer in an end-filling or PCR reaction to incorporate the fluorescent label onto one end of the DNA fragment.)

        Option 3.1.4: Non-radioactive labeling using a biotinylated primer.
            - Component A: DNA fragment
            - Component B: biotin marker
            - Component C: DNA polymerase
            - Component D: dNTPs
            (operational details: Chemically or enzymatically attach a biotin marker to an oligonucleotide primer and use it in an end-filling reaction to label the DNA fragment.)

    Step 3.2: Perform base-specific chemical cleavage reactions.

        Option 3.2.1: Four-lane chemical cleavage.
            - Component A: End-labeled DNA
            - Component B: Dimethyl sulphate (DMS)
            - Component C: Hydrazine
            - Component D: NaCl
            - Component E: piperidine
            (operational details: Aliquot the end-labeled DNA into four tubes and perform the following parallel reactions: 1) G+A cleavage: Treat with DMS followed by heating at pH 7/0.1 M alkali at 90 °C. 2) A+G cleavage: Treat with DMS-acid/alkali. 3) C+T cleavage: Treat with hydrazine at 20 °C. 4) C cleavage: Treat with hydrazine in 2 M NaCl. Follow all reactions with treatment with hot aqueous piperidine to cleave the DNA backbone at the modified base positions.)

        Option 3.2.2: Two-lane formamide cleavage.
            - Component A: End-labeled DNA
            - Component B: Methylene Blue
            - Component C: formamide
            (operational details: Divide the sample into two. One sample is subjected to a photoreaction with Methylene Blue. Both samples are then heated in the presence of formamide, which cleaves the phosphodiester bond at A, C, and G residues. The pretreatment creates a bias between A and G cleavage, allowing for differentiation across two lanes.)

        Option 3.2.3: One-lane solvolysis cleavage.
            - Component A: End-labeled DNA
            - Component B: aqueous piperidine (10%)
            - Component C: formamide
            (operational details: Perform solvolysis by treating the sample with hot aqueous piperidine followed by hot formamide. The relative intensities of the resulting bands for the four bases are used to determine the sequence in a single gel lane.)

    Step 3.3: Separate and detect cleaved fragments.

        Option 3.3.1: Polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and autoradiography.
            - Component A: Products from chemical cleavage reactions
            - Component B: Denaturing polyacrylamide gel
            - Component C: Photographic film
            (operational details: Separate the nested sets of labeled fragments on a high-resolution denaturing polyacrylamide gel. Expose the gel to film to visualize the bands corresponding to the radiolabeled fragments.)

        Option 3.3.2: Chemiluminescent detection.
            - Component A: Products from biotin-labeled cleavage reactions
            - Component B: Nylon membrane
            - Component C: DNA oligonucleotides labelled with alkaline phosphatase or biotin
            - Component D: streptavidin conjugate (if needed)
            - Component E: Chemiluminescent substrate (AMPPD)
            - Component F: Photographic film
            (operational details: Transfer the separated DNA fragments from the gel to a nylon membrane. Hybridize with labeled probes. Soak the membrane in a chemiluminescent substrate and expose to film to detect the light emitted at the band positions.)

        Option 3.3.3: MALDI-TOF Mass Spectrometry.
            - Component A: Products from chemical cleavage reactions
            - Component B: Energy-absorbing matrix
            (operational details: Analyze the mass of the cleaved fragments using MALDI-TOF MS to determine the sequence.)

Part 4: Pyrosequencing

    Step 4.1: Prepare the sequencing reaction.

        Option 4.1.1: Solid-phase (three-enzyme) system.
            - Component A: Immobilized ssDNA template (e.g., on streptavidin-coated magnetic beads)
            - Component B: sequencing primer
            - Component C: DNA polymerase
            - Component D: ATP sulphurylase
            - Component E: Luciferase
            - Component F: Adenosine 5′-phosphosulphate (APS)
            - Component G: luciferin
            (operational details: Anneal the primer to the immobilized template. Prepare a reaction mixture containing the three enzymes, APS, and luciferin. This system requires washing steps between nucleotide additions.)

        Option 4.1.2: Liquid-phase (four-enzyme) system.
            - Component A: ssDNA template in solution
            - Component B: sequencing primer
            - Component C: DNA polymerase
            - Component D: ATP sulphurylase
            - Component E: Luciferase
            - Component F: apyrase
            - Component G: Adenosine 5′-phosphosulphate (APS)
            - Component H: luciferin
            (operational details: Anneal the primer to the template in solution. Prepare a reaction mixture containing all four enzymes (including the nucleotide-degrading apyrase), APS, and luciferin. This system does not require intermediate washing steps.)

        Option 4.1.3: Improved system with ssDNA-binding proteins.
            - Component A: Components from Option 4.1.1 or 4.1.2
            - Component B: ssDNA-binding proteins (SSB)
            (operational details: Add SSB to either the solid-phase or liquid-phase reaction mixture to minimize non-specific primer binding and improve signal intensity.)

    Step 4.2: Perform sequential nucleotide incorporation and detection.

        Option 4.2.1: Sequential addition of standard dNTPs.
            - Component A: Prepared pyrosequencing reaction from Step 4.1
            - Component B: dATP
            - Component C: dCTP
            - Component D: dGTP
            - Component E: dTTP
            (operational details: Sequentially add one dNTP at a time to the reaction. If the nucleotide is incorporated by DNA polymerase, pyrophosphate (PPi) is released, triggering the enzymatic cascade that produces light. The light is measured by a detector. Unincorporated nucleotides are washed away (solid-phase) or degraded by apyrase (liquid-phase) before the next dNTP is added.)

        Option 4.2.2: Sequential addition using dATPαS.
            - Component A: Prepared pyrosequencing reaction from Step 4.1
            - Component B: dATPαS
            - Component C: dCTP
            - Component D: dGTP
            - Component E: dTTP
            (operational details: Perform the sequential addition as in Option 4.2.1, but substitute dATP with dATPαS. dATPαS is incorporated by DNA polymerase but is not a substrate for luciferase, thus preventing false signals from residual dATP interfering with the light detection reaction.)

Part 5: Single Molecule Sequencing with Exonuclease

    Step 5.1: Prepare and immobilize a single labeled DNA molecule.

        Option 5.1.1: Complete fluorescent labeling and immobilization.
            - Component A: dsDNA fragment
            - Component B: Fluorescently labeled nucleotides (each of the four bases labeled with a distinct dye)
            - Component C: 5′-biotinylated DNA strand
            - Component D: streptavidin-coated microsphere
            (operational details: Synthesize or label one strand of a DNA fragment such that every base is fluorescently labeled. Ensure the labeled strand has a 5'-biotin tag. Attach a single labeled DNA molecule to a single streptavidin-coated microsphere.)

    Step 5.2: Perform exonuclease digestion and detection.

        Option 5.2.1: Flow-based cleavage and detection.
            - Component A: Microsphere with attached single DNA molecule
            - Component B: flowing buffer stream
            - Component C: exonuclease
            (operational details: Suspend the microsphere in a flowing buffer stream. Introduce an exonuclease, which binds to the 3'-end of the DNA and sequentially cleaves the labeled nucleotide monophosphates. As each labeled base is cleaved, it is carried by the flow stream through a focused laser beam for detection and identification based on its unique fluorescence.)
